title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Barclays said it is buying back a slug of structured notes at a loss of about $591 million after selling too many of them. The bank said it is conducting a review of the matter.

---

Walmart is ending cigarette sales in some U.S. stores after years of debate within the retailer's leadership ranks about the sale of tobacco products.

---

Tesla said it would request shareholder approval for an increase in the number of the company's shares to enable a stock split.

---

FedEx founder Fred Smith is stepping down as CEO and will hand the role to operating chief Raj Subramaniam on June 1.

---

Former World Bank chief Georgieva, who now leads the IMF, knew about a top official's sexual misconduct but failed to take any action, according to current and former bank staff.

---

U.S. lawmakers asked Credit Suisse to hand over information related to the bank's compliance with sanctions over Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

---

U.S. stocks closed higher in a choppy session, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow adding 0.7%, 1.3% and 0.3%, respectively.

---

The Commerce Department said it would investigate whether Chinese solar producers are illegally circumventing solar tariffs.

---

HP Inc. agreed to acquire Poly, a maker of workplace communications products, for $1.7 billion.
